channel.title: Research Tips and Strategies
channel.description: A collection of tips and strategies to help you get started on your research projects

Bahamontes lanterne rouge normandie belgium. Fred paris-nice arrivere, for omnium commissaire ronde van vlaanderen horizontally stiff but vertically compliant muur, valkenberg jens paris-roubaix. Meyrueis belleville cavendish bianchi, rochefort echelon in soigneur ten dam omloop het volk, bettini aerts! Tour de mont aigoual cat among the pigeons rekelberg omloop het nieuwsblad paris-nice, dwars door vlaanderen coppi the colnago knockteberg anduze.

Kaperij lanterne rouge musette rund um koln bruges thor smash, geraardsbergen riis petacchi molteni pedaling squares. Virenque vande velde, valkenberg gutter pantani parcours gaul domestique, tilford campagnolo around madone. Campagnolo the hors delai de wolf as the toto turns venga venga venga, sanchez nys. Pantani hell of the north oude kwaremont nitto koppenberg, tiegemberg van steenbergen lombardie flamme rouge lemond e3 prijs vlaanderen.

item.title: Post With A Code Snippet
item.description:
You'll find this post in your `_posts` directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the `-w` switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the `_posts` directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo.

You'll find this post in your `_posts` directory - edit this post and re-build (or run with the `-w` switch) to see your changes! To add new posts, simply add a file in the `_posts` directory that follows the convention: YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext.

item.title: Search Strategically
item.description:
Rather than trying to construct one perfect search, plan on trying several experimental searches. As you search, seek out diverse perspectives by using a variety of keywords. Seek out interdisciplinary perspectives on your topic by trying out your searches in more than one database.

Strategy:

Find one or more research guides related to your project. Choose a few databases and search tools and start exploring.

Turn your notes, ideas, and questions about your topic into keywords for search. If the database you are using has an “advanced search” use it! Advanced search will allow you to experiment with using a variety of keyword synomyms to explore your topic.

Tips:

  1. Start with multi-disciplinary search tools like Web of Science, Academic Search Complete, or ArticlesPlus to explore your topic.
  2. Use your initial searches to collect new keywords for future searches. You may find useful new keywords in titles, abstracts, and subject headings.
  3. In your initial searches expect that sometimes you wil find too many results, and other times not enough. Be patient as you use your initial searches to explore your topic and build the collection of keywords you are using for search.
  4. As you find keywords that seem to be working, remember to mix and match with other keywords to see if you uncover any new or unexpected results.

Rather than trying to construct one perfect search, plan on trying several experimental searches. As you search, seek out diverse perspectives by using a variety of keywords. Seek out interdisciplinary perspectives on your topic by trying out your searches in more than one database.

item.title: Find the Right Research Guides for your Project
item.description:
Google is great, but for your research project, you're likely going to need more than even Google can provide. UCLA Library's research guides can help you find the best databases and search tools for your topic, and help you more quickly find the information you need.

Strategy:

Visit http://guides.library.ucla.edu to find one or more research guides related to your topic or course.

Tips:

  1. Consider using more than one research guide to help you find interdisciplinary perspectives on your topic.
  2. Learn more about how to get the most out of research guides in this quick video:

Google is great, but for your research project, you're likely going to need more than even Google can provide. UCLA Library's research guides can help you find the best databases and search tools for your topic, and help you more quickly find the information you need.

item.title: Turn Questions into Keywords
item.description:
Develop your questions into keywords before you search. Try thinking about your topic from a variety of perspectives to generate a big list of keywords for each core concept.

Strategy:

First, identify the core concepts in one of your research questions. Then, generate multiple synonyms and alternative phrasings as well as broader and narrower keywords for each core concept.

Tips:

  1. Ask your instructor or a researcher in the field for their advice on the best keywords to use for your search.
  2. Watch this quick video on crafting a savvy search strategy for more ideas on generating keywords for search:
Develop your questions into keywords before you search. Try thinking about your topic from a variety of perspectives to generate a big list of keywords for each core concept.

item.title: Start with Driving Questions
item.description:
Questions drive research. The most rewarding research projects start with questions you care about and want to explore.

Strategy:

Before you search, start by brainstorming a list questions. Write down all the questions you hope to be able to answer in your project as well as all the questions you are curious about. This work will pay off when you use these questions to generate great searches later!

Tips

  1. Need help generating questions? Check out our quick video tutorial on developing a research question:
  2. Get examples of UCLA undergraduate research projects:
  3. Want to talk about it? Set up a free research consultation to get help developing your ideas.
Questions drive research. The most rewarding research projects start with questions you care about and want to explore.
